related.description: A number of education trends made their mark in 2013, from massive open online courses to evaluating colleges based on their graduation rates. The underlying forces that drove change this year aren't likely to change anytime soon: declining public funding, changing demographics, advancing technology, and a tough job market.
related.title: 5 Higher-Education Trends for 2014

related.description: Universities in South Dakota, Nebraska, and other states have cut the number of credits students need to graduate. A proposal in Florida would let online courses forgo the usual higher-education accreditation process. A California legislator introduced a measure that would have substituted online courses for some of the brick-and-mortar kind at public universities.
related.title: 'We Are Creating Walmarts of Higher Education'

related.description: When Daquan McGee got accepted to the Borough of Manhattan Community College in the spring of 2010, he was 19 and still finding his footing after a two-year prison sentence for attempted robbery. He signed up for the standard battery of placement tests in reading, writing, and math; took them cold; and failed two-writing and math.
related.title: How to Escape the Community-College Trap

related.description: Two years after a Stanford professor drew 160,000 students from around the globe to a free online course on artificial intelligence, starting what was widely viewed as a revolution in higher education, early results for such large-scale courses are disappointing, forcing a rethinking of how college instruction can best use the Internet.
related.title: After Setbacks, Online Courses Are Rethought

related.description: In the world of higher education, 2013 was a wild year. Thanks to the Internet and social media, students gained notoriety as the "Deranged Sorority Girl" and the "Drunkest College Student Ever," and professors learned that fat-shaming tweets could affect their employment prospects.
related.title: Meet The People Who Made The Biggest Impact In Higher Ed This Year

title: Solidarity with Free Cooper Union
content:
Students at Cooper Union are organising against their management's plans to charge tuition fees for the first time in the institution's 110 year history. They are occupying and fighting to save free education at Cooper and to demand radical changes to the way it is governed. This is a landmark struggle, and we support it.

We write to you to express our solidarity with your struggle to maintain free education at Cooper Union. In England, we had free undergraduate tuition until 15 years ago, when the Labour (social-democratic) Party introduced tuition fees. Then came 'top-up fees' in 2003, and from this year the Conservative-Liberal coalition has imposed undergraduate tuition fees of £9,000 (~$14,500) a year, with graduate courses and fees for international students often double that. This is a huge and rapid transition: funding for higher education has passed from the state to the debt-laden individual; education is now a commodity to buy, a loan taken out against (increasingly unlikely) future earnings, a commodity defined by its impact on the economy rather than contribution to society. University applications are down by 10% this year, as the young, the poor, those with dependents, and the sensible, baulk at accumulating £60,000 debt, including living costs, for an undergraduate degree.

In this same time we have seen the growth of the managerial, neo-liberal university administrations that view colleges as businesses, students as consumers, overseas students as cash cows, teachers as exploitable labour, and cleaners as a marginal service workforce to be farmed out to greedy contractors. UCL management are right now in negotiations to demolish a housing estate in Stratford to build a new campus, destroying the local community.

The student movement in the UK has not been good enough at articulating a radical vision for free education. At every juncture, our "leaders" fought for the status quo, and this is where we find ourselves. Our experience is that making radical principled demands, not moderated ones, is the only way to oppose neo-liberal economic policies in education. Never give up the fight. You have the students and the academics with you; who else is there?
